## 2 Model  

I consider an extension of the model in Donangelo et al. (2019) to interpret the empirical findings presented in the previous section. One departure point from that model is to consider capital accumulation through investments. A second departure point is the inclusion of two independent regime-switching processes that drive cross-sectional differences in growth rates across firms. The first regime-switching process is aggregate and drives the failure of the both the conditional CAPM and the unconditional CAPM in explaining the value premium. The second regime-switching process is firm specific and represents the drivers that complement labor leverage in explaining cross-sectional differences in returns and growth rates. At the end of this section, I present a calibration exercise that shows how this extended model can generate the value premium decomposition moments, as well as a number of relevant financial and macroeconomic moments, that are comparable to those found in the data.  

### 2.1 Setup  

I follow Berk et al. (1999) by considering the pricing kernel as exogenous in order to maintain the tractability of the model and to maintain my focus on the effect of micro-level decisions on firm risk. The dynamics of the pricing kernel $\Lambda$ are givenby  

$$
\frac{d\Lambda_{t}}{\Lambda_{t}}=-r d t-\eta[\vartheta_{t}]d Z_{t}^{\Lambda},
$$  

where $r>0$ is the instantaneous risk-free rate, $\eta>0$ represents the market price of risk in the economy, and $Z^{\Lambda}$ is a Wiener process that represents the single source of priced risk in the economy. The systematic two-state Markov process $\vartheta$ governs the level of the market price of risk and the purchase cost of capital. This shock is introduced to drive the failure of the CAPM to explain the value premium in the model. The two states are $\vartheta\in\{\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}},\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}\}$ . The market price of risk is lower in the $\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}$ state than in the $\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}$ ， $\eta[\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}]\leq\eta[\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}]$ . The process $\vartheta$ is orthogonal to all other stochastic processes in the model. The transition probability of the process $\vartheta$ over an infinitesimal time interval $d t$ is symmetric and is given by  

$$
\left[\begin{array}{l l}{1-p_{\vartheta}d t}&{p_{\vartheta}d t}\ {p_{\vartheta}d t}&{1-p_{\vartheta}d t}\end{array}\right],
$$  

where $p_{\vartheta}\geq0$ is the transition intensity from states $\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}$ to $\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}$ and from $\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}$ to $\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}$  

The model represents a small wage- and price-taking firm that continuously optimizes labor hiring and capital investment. Labor $L$ is combined with capital $K$ to generatevalue added $Y$ according to the following constant elasticity of substitution (CES) production function:  

$$
Y_{t}=\left(\alpha(X_{t}L_{t})^{\frac{\theta-1}{\theta}}+(1-\alpha)K_{t}^{\frac{\theta-1}{\theta}}\right)^{\frac{\theta}{\theta-1}},
$$  

where $L>0$ and $K>0$ denote the labor and capital employed in production, $X$ denotes the labor-augmenting productivity, $\alpha\in(0,1)$ captures the weight of labor in the productive technology, and $\theta\in(0,\infty)$ denotes the labor-capital elasticity of substitution. The production function in Equation (18) nests the widely used Cobb-Douglas production function when $\theta\rightarrow1$ , which is the knife-edge case in which labor and capital are not complements nor substitutes to each another. The case in which $\theta>1$ implies that capital and labor are strictly substitutes. The case in which the elasticity $\theta<1$ is the most empirically relevant, because it implies that capital and labor are strictly complements.?21 Operating profits are given by $Y_{t}-W_{t}L_{t}$  

Capital $K$ follows the law of motion given by  

$$
d K_{t}=K_{t}(1-\delta)d t+\iota_{\mathrm{s,t}}d t+\iota_{\mathrm{p,t}}d t,
$$  

where $\delta\in[0,1)$ is the depreciation rate, ${\iota_{\mathrm{s}}}\leq0$ is disinvestment (i.e., sale of capital), and $\iota_{\mathrm{p}}\geq0$ is investment (i.e., purchase of capital). The investment decision is subject to  

adjustment costs and to partial capital reversibility as in Abel and Eberly (1994) and Abel and Eberly (1997), and is given by the investment cost function  

$$
\Phi\left[\iota_{\mathrm{s,t}},\iota_{\mathrm{p,t}},\vartheta_{t}\right]=\frac{c_{\mathrm{k}}}{2}\left(\iota_{\mathrm{s,t}}^{2}+\iota_{\mathrm{p,t}}^{2}\right)+\iota_{\mathrm{s,t}}\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}+\iota_{\mathrm{p,t}}\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}[\vartheta_{t}],
$$  

where $c_{\mathrm{k}}\geq0$ is a nonnegative constant related to the level of capital adjustment costs and $\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}~\geq~0$ and $\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}~>~0$ are the prices at which the firm is able to sell and purchase capital, respectively. To rule out arbitrage opportunities in the market for capital, the selling price is restricted to be equal or lower than the purchasing price, $\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}\leq\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}$ . The wedge between the purchase and selling prices of capital captures the degree of irreversibility of capital. The extreme case of fully reversible capital is given by $\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}~=~\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}$ and the extreme case of fully irreversible capital is given by $\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}~=~0$ . The case with partial capital reversibility is given by $0<\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}<\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}$ . The purchase price of capital is driven by the aggregate regime $\vartheta$ Specifically, the purchase price of capital is higher in the good regime than in the bad regime, $\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}[\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}]\geq\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}[\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}]$  

Productivity, $X$ , follows the diffusion process given by  

$$
\frac{d X_{t}}{X_{t}}=\mu_{\mathrm{x}}[\omega_{t}]d t+\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}\rho_{\mathrm{x}}d Z_{t}^{\Lambda}+\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}\sqrt{1-\rho_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}}d Z_{t}^{\mathrm{x}},
$$  

where $\mu_{\mathrm{x}}$ and $\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}$ are the drift and volatility of productivity growth, $\rho_{\mathrm{x}}$ represents the pricedrisk loading of productivity growth, and $Z^{\mathrm{{x}}}$ is a Wiener proces that is idiosyncratic (i.e., frm specific) and orthogonal to $Z^{\Lambda}$ (i.e., $\operatorname{E}[d Z^{\mathrm{x}}d Z^{\mathrm{\Lambda}}]=0$ ). The growth rate of productivity, $\mu_{\mathrm{X}}$ is determined by a firm-specific two-state Markov process $\omega$ . The process $\omega$ is orthogonal to all other stochastic processes in the model, $Z^{\Lambda},Z^{\mathrm{x}},Z^{\mathrm{w}}$ , and $\vartheta$ . The state space for $\omega$ is given by $\omega\in\{\omega^{\mathrm{fast}},\omega^{\mathrm{slow}}\}$ , where the superscripts refer to firm-specific states of fast and a slow productivity growth: $\mu_{\mathrm{x}}[\omega^{\mathrm{tast}}]\geq\mu_{\mathrm{x}}[\omega^{\mathrm{slow}}]$ . The transition probability of the process $\omega$ over an infinitesimal time interval $d t$ is symmetric and is given by  

$$
\left[\begin{array}{l l}{1-p_{\omega}d t}&{p_{\omega}d t}\ {p_{\omega}d t}&{1-p_{\omega}d t}\end{array}\right],
$$  

where $p_{\omega}\geq0$ is the transition intensity from states $\omega^{\mathrm{fast}}$ to $\boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{slow}}$ and from $\boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{slow}}$ to $\omega^{\mathrm{fast}}$  

The firm has access to a perfectly competitive labor market, so it must always pay the current level of aggregate wages to its workers. The dynamics of aggregate wages $W$ are givenby  

$$
\frac{d W_{t}}{W_{t}}=\mu_{\mathrm{w}}{d t}+\sigma_{\mathrm{w}}\rho_{\mathrm{w}}{d\boldsymbol{Z}_{t}^{\Lambda}}+\sigma_{\mathrm{w}}\sqrt{1-\rho_{\mathrm{w}}^{2}}{d\boldsymbol{Z}_{t}^{\mathrm{w}}},
$$  

where $\mu_{\mathrm{w}}$ and $\sigma_{\mathrm{w}}$ are the drift and volatility of wage growth, $\rho_{\mathrm{w}}$ represents the pricedrisk loading of wage growth, and $Z^{\mathrm{w}}$ is a Wiener process that captures the component of aggregate wage growth shocks that is not priced (i.e., $\operatorname{E}[d Z^{\mathrm{w}}d Z]=0$ 一  

Finally, firms are subject to technology obsolescence shocks in which productivity (and thus firm value) suddenly collapse to zero. Technology obsolescence is an absorbing state that is triggered by an idiosyncratic shock that follows a Poisson process with instantaneous intensity $\lambda_{d}d t$ . The firm obsolescence process is introduced in the model to avoid numerical problems in the calibration exercise presented at the end of the section.22

### 2.3 Model calibration  

The discussion in the previous section focuses on the comparative statics of the analytical model solution. This section presents the results of a numerical exercise based on artificial data from a large number of simulations, each of which represents a large panel of firms. The model is calibrated to minimize the distance between the moments constructed from artificial data generated by the model and the moments constructed from real-world data. In particular, the main goal of the calibration presented in this section is to verify that the model can, under reasonable parameter values, produce point estimates from the baseline and extended value spread decompositions that are close to those presented in Table 1. In addition, this calibration exercise attempts to match the moments related to macroeconomic variables and stock returns, which are described in Appendix D.  

#### 2.3.1 Calibration procedure.  

The calibrated procedure is as follows: I first run 1,0oo simulations, each consisting of the histories of 1,000 firms over 66 years at a monthly frequency. The initial levels of productivity, wages, and capital are identical for all firm at the start of each simulation and for new firms that replace firms hit by obsolescence shocks. The first 50 years of each simulation are discarded and are only used to generate the cross-sectional distributions of firm-level productivity, wages, and capital. The simulated variables from the last 16 years of each simulation, which I denote years $t=0$ , .., 15, are then converted from monthly to annual frequency. Firms with over 5 years of age between years $t=0$ and $t=16$ are then used in the decomposition. At $t=0$ $1$ form twenty portfolios of firms sorted by their lagged bookto-market ratios and construct the variables used in the decomposition up to year $t=15$ Finally, the constructed variables of each simulation are combined into a single synthetic data set used to produce a total of 90 synthetic moments that target moments from the data. Table 5 reports these moments, which I will discuss later.  

The model simulation requires the definition of 24 parameters values, all of which are shown in Table 3. Of these 24 parameters, 7 are not calibrated and are instead fixed. The risk-free rate $r$ is set to 0.02. The initial level of capital of a new firm $\mathrm{K}_{0}\mathrm{~=~}0$ (i.e., new firms start with no capital). The initial levels of productivity ( $\mathrm{X}_{0}=2.305$ ) and wages ( $\mathrm{W}_{0}=$ 1) are set so that the initial labor share in the sample matches that from the data. The labor-capital elasticity of substitution, $\theta$ , is fixed at 0.40, which is close to the center of the range of estimates reported in the literature (e.g., Leon-Ledesma et al. 2010; Klump et al. 2012). The technological obsolescence rate $\lambda_{\mathrm{d}}$ is set to 0.02 which is consistent with the literature (e.g., Carlson et al. 2004). The capital depreciation rate $\delta$ is set to 0.12, which is the value used in Belo et al. (2014).  

The remaining seventeen parameters shown in Table 3 are calibrated to fit the moments from the data. The aggregate regime-switching process is included in the model to represent time variation in discount rates and investment specific shocks. The table shows that the calibration produces two distinct productivity growth regimes. The transition probability across the bad and good states, $p_{\vartheta}$ , is 0.096. The market price of risk is $\eta[\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}]=0.774$ in the bad state and $\eta[\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}]=0.001$ in the good state.  

The parameters that are related to the second moments of productivity growth ( $\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}$ and $\rho_{\mathrm{x}}$ ) and of wage growth ( $\sigma_{\mathrm{w}}$ and $\rho_{\mathrm{w}}$ ) are jointly determined as to match the target moments related to macroeconomic variables shown in Table 5. The firm-specific two-state regimeswitching process is included in the model to drive cross-sectional variation in expected future cash fow growth rates. Table 3 shows that the calibration produces two distinct productivity growth regimes. The symmetric transition probability across these two states, $p_{\omega}$ , is 0.233, which indicates that the regimes are somewhat persistent. The parameter values for the drift of the productivity growth rate in each of these states indicate that the two regimes incidentally corroborate the labels used (i.e., good and bad). Productivity growth is lower in the slow growth state $\mu_{\mathrm{X}}[\omega^{\mathrm{slow}}]=0.021$ than in the fast growth state $\mu_{\mathrm{X}}[\omega^{\mathrm{tast}}]=0.029$ . The drift of wage growth rate $\mu_{\mathrm{w}}=0.008$ and the weight of labor in the production function $\alpha=0.364$ are mainly determined the average level and the average cross-sectional standard deviation of labor share in the sample. The adjustment cost multiplier $c=0.068$ , the sale price of capital $\kappa_{\mathrm{s}}=0.180$ , and the purchase prices of capital in the bad state $\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}[\vartheta^{\mathrm{bad}}]=0.803$ and good state $\kappa_{\mathrm{p}}[\vartheta^{\mathrm{good}}]=2.495$ are mainly driven by the cross-sectional moments related to investment rate and by the decomposition weights. Finally, the value of the constant $\rho$ is set to 0.923 so that the sum of the three components of the baseline decomposition is approximately one across the horizons.

The failure of the unconditional CAPM is more evident than that of the conditional CAPM, as suggested by the wide alphas of the HML portfolio (3.866% in the model vs. 4.277% in the data). The same reasons that make the conditional CAPM fail in the model also make the unconditional CAPM (e.g., the existence of priced shocks orthogonal to the returns of the market portfolio). In addition, the fact that the conditional beta of the HML portfolio is strongly positively correlated with the market portfolio represents another source of model misspecification that exacerbates the failure of the unconditional CAPM relative to the conditional CAPM.

To see this, note that a true priced-risk loading $\beta$ related to some possibly unknown asset pricing factor model $R_{i,t}=\alpha+\beta_{i}R_{M,t}+\epsilon_{i,t}$ can be decomposed into two parts:

## 4 Conclusion  

The goal of this paper is to quantify the relative importance of labor leverage in explaining the positive cross-sectional relation between book-to-market ratios and stock returns (i.e. the value premium). My analysis uses a novel extension of the value spread decomposition methodology from Cohen et al. (2003, CPV). I use this extension to gauge the extent to which labor leverage, which is proxied by labor share, can explain the value premium and the growth spread. One of the main findings of this paper is that labor leverage is an essential, but not a unique, determinant of the value premium. Another key finding is that labor leverage does not seem to be a primary determinant of the growth spread. When these two facts are considered together, they provide indirect evidence for the existence of additional economic mechanisms that are unrelated to labor leverage, are essential for explaining the value premium, and likely are related to drivers of firm growth.  

The paper proposes a labor-based model that represents a set of sufficient, but not necessary, conditions that can explain the main empirical findings. In the model, as in the data, labor leverage seems to be an essential, but not a unique, determinant of the value premium. In the model, the firm is subject to labor-induced operating leverage that originates from the strict complementarity between labor and capital and from the smoothness of economywide wages. This model shows that labor share is a valid proxy for labor leverage because it is negatively related to productivity and thus negatively related to profits. Despite its tractability, the model is fexible enough to also represent economic mechanisms unrelated to labor leverage that also drive the value premium (e.g., mechanisms based on growth options or investment-specific shocks). Moreover, the model can qualitatively and quantitatively explain the results from the baseline value spread decomposition from CPV as well as the results from the extended decomposition of the value premium and of the growth spread.  

Underlying this paper is the idea that book-to-market ratios are a catch-all firm characteristic that embed any determinants of firms’ discount rates and growth rates. The findings of this paper are consistent with the hypothesis that not all determinants of firms’ growth rates are also determinants of firms’ discount rates. Overall, these findings cast further doubt on the perception that a low book-to-market ratio is the defining property of a growth firm.

#### A.5 Boundary Conditions  

Economic arguments about the limiting cases $\psi\rightarrow-\infty$ and $\psi\to\infty$ define the values of 8 of the 16 constants in vectors $\mathbf{C}^{\mathrm{{A}}}$ and $\mathbf{C}^{1}$ . In particular, the aforementioned parameter space restriction, which ensures that four of the eigenvalues are negative and four are positive, implies that 8 of the 16 constants must equal zero. To see this, first consider the marginal value of the assets in place $q$ of an active firm. The complementary component of $q$ in this case represents the value of the option to suspend operations to prevent operating profits from becoming negative. It logically follows that, to rule out the counterfactual case in which the value of the suspension option from becoming arbitrarily large as the firm moves away from the option's exercise threshold (i.e., as $\psi\rightarrow-\infty$ ), I must have that $\mathbf{C}_{i}^{\mathrm{{A}}}=0\forall i$ s.t. $\lambda_{i}<0$ . A similar argument holds for the inactive frm region. Note that an inactive frm does not generate any cash fows, so the marginal value of the assets in place $q$ in this case is simply the value of the option to resume operations when conditions make it profitable to do so. It reasons that $\mathbf{C}_{i}^{\mathrm{{I}}}=0\forall i$ s.t. $\lambda_{i}\geq0$ to prevent the value of the option to resume operations from becoming arbitrarily large as the firm moves away from the option's exercise threshold (i.e., as $\psi\to\infty$  

The remaining eight constants are determined by the value matching conditions at the threshold $\psi={\overline{{\psi}}}$ (i.e., the threshold in which firms switch their operational status), which aregivenby  

$$
{\bf q}^{\mathrm{A}}[\psi_{t}]\Bigg|_{\psi_{t}=\overline{{{\psi}}}}={\bf q}^{\mathrm{I}}[\psi_{t}]\Bigg|_{\psi_{t}=\overline{{{\psi}}}}.
$$  

The system in Equation (A19) above contains eight equalities and eight nonzero constants to be determined. The solution to the system is given by  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\mathbf{C}_{i}^{\mathrm{A}}=}&{\left(\frac{\Gamma\left[\frac{2-\theta}{1-\theta}\right]\Gamma\left[-\lambda_{i}\right]}{\Gamma\left[\frac{2-\theta}{1-\theta}\right]-\lambda_{i}}\right)\mathbb{1}_{\{\lambda_{\mathrm{i}}>0\}}\qquad\mathrm{and}}\ {\mathbf{C}_{i}^{\mathrm{I}}=-\left(\frac{\Gamma\left[\frac{2-\theta}{1-\theta}\right]\Gamma\left[-\lambda_{i}\right]}{\Gamma\left[\frac{2-\theta}{1-\theta}\right]-\lambda_{i}}\right)\mathbb{1}_{\{\lambda_{\mathrm{i}}\leq0\}},\quad\forall i\in\{1,...,8\},}\end{array}
$$  

where $\Gamma[.]$ is the gamma function.

### B Accounting and Financial Data  

Monthly common stock data are from the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP shrcd =10 or 11). Accounting information is taken from Standard and Poor's Compustat annual industrial files. I include only stocks listed on NYSE, AMEX, and NASDAQ, with available data in the CRSP-Compustat merged files. I follow the literature and exclude firms with primary standard industrial classifications between 6000 and 6999 (financials). Size is defined as the market value of equity (Compustat variables prc times shrout). The book-value of equity is defined as in Daniel and Titman (2006). The book-to-market ratio is defined as book value of equity over size. Book value is defined as shareholders’ equity (Compustat SEQ) divided by the market value of equity. I exclude firm-year observations with missing monthly returns in the year and/or with missing or negative measures of size, book-to-market, and labor share in the previous year. When labor share LS is negative or greater than 1, I drop the firm-year observation. Market values and accounting variables are Winsorized at the 0.5% level in each sample year to reduce the infuence of possible outliers. The data used to construct the target moments in the panels F-H in Table 5 are at the monthly frequency and obtained from Kenneth French's data library. Specifically, the returns are based on the value-weighted returns of the quintile portfolios of firms sorted on B/M minus the 1-month Treasury-bill rate. The conditional betas are constructed from yearly univariate regressions of the portfolio's excess returns on the market factor return. The alpha is constructed as the full sample mean of the difference between the realized returns and the product of the conditional beta and the market factor return. The equity returns in the calibrated model are defined as the portfolio's asset return divided by one minus the leverage ratio of the quintile portfolio from the data reported in Table 2. The market factor return from the model is constructed as the value-weighted asset return of the firms in the simulated sample divided by one minus the weighted average financial leverage ratio from the data.  

### C Value Spread Decompositions: Implementation Details  

For each year in the sample, I form twenty portfolios of frms sorted on the previous year's B/M ratio. For each portfolio, I construct the measure of book value (B), market value (M), and dividends (D) by summing the respective firm-level variables. The variables used in the decompositions are constructed following CPV. I construct portfolio-level log B/M as $b m_{i t}\equiv\mathrm{Log}[^{B_{i t}}/M_{i t}]$ . I follow CPV and approximate log earnings and log gross returns by applying Taylor expansions around the same expansion point $\rho$ . Specifically, I construct portfolio-level log earnings as $e_{i t}\equiv\mathrm{Log}\left[{{D}_{i t}}/{{B}_{i,t-1}}\right]-\rho\mathrm{Log}\left[{{{D}_{i t}}}/{{B}_{i,t}}\right]$ , and log returns as $r_{i t}\equiv\mathrm{Log}\left[D_{i t}/M_{i,t-1}\right]-\rho\mathrm{Log}\left[D_{i t}/M_{i,t}\right]$ . I set the value of the decomposition constant to 0.96 in the data.  

The baseline methodology is similar, but not identical, to the methodology in CPV. As discussed in the main text, one difference is that I decompose the term related to ROE in the original methodology into two terms, one related to ROE level and one related to ROE future growth. Another difference is that, in this stage, I use a Fama-MacBeth procedure as opposed to panel data regressions. The use of cross-sectional regressions does not materially change the estimated weights; and, as it will become clear later in this section, this procedure allows me to extend the methodology to further decompose contemporaneous bm into components explained by, and orthogonal to, labor shares. The use of the Fama-MacBeth procedure affects the appropriate way of computing standard errors. Whereas CPV employs Rogers standard errors, I use Newey-West standard errors, in which the number of lags matches the horizon considered in the second-stage estimates of the Fama-MacBeth procedure shown in Equation (8). Another difference in my baseline procedure is that I use twenty portfolios of firms sorted on lagged B/M, whereas CPV use forty portfolios. The main reason for using fewer portfolios is to counteract the smaller sample of firm-year observations with nonmissing labor share. In practice, using fewer portfolios avoids the occurrence of portfolio-year-horizon observations that include too few firms, over longer horizons in particular.  

### DConstruction Details of the Moments from Table 5  

This appendix provides additional details on the construction the empirical and modelgenerated moments presented in Table 5, panels D-H.  

The target moments in panel D (Macroeconomic moments） of Table 5 are the average labor share and the volatilities and cross-correlations of real GDP growth, real wage growth, and by real TFP growth. These moments are constructed as in Donangelo et al. (2019). The average and cross-sectional standard deviation of labor share are defined as the timeseries averages of the cross-sectional average and standard deviation of firm-level labor share measure $L S$ , respectively. The real GDP, TFP, and real wage growth series cover the nonfarm business sector. The real GDP growth series is taken from the NIPA table 1.1.3 and is calculated as the log change of real GDP. I follow Arias, Hansen, and Ohanian (2007) and calculate log TFP growth as $\begin{array}{r}{\Delta\log\left[Y\right]-\frac{2}{3}\Delta\log\left[H\right]}\end{array}$ , where $\Delta\log\left[Y\right]$ is the real GDP series and $\mathrm{Log}\left[H\right]$ is the hours of all persons (BLS series PRS85006033). The real wage series is constructed as the log growth in real hourly compensation (BLS series PRS85006153). The TFP and real wage growth series are annualized from the quarterly seasonally adjusted series from the BLS.  

The target moments in panel E (Asset returns of equal-weighted LS-quintile portfolios) of Table 5 are constructed as the equal-weighted unlevered annual excess stock returns of the quintile portfolios formed by lagged labor share with merged CRSP-Compustat data from 1963 to 2017. Unlevered returns are defined as (stock returns in excess of the 1- month Treasury-bill rate) $\times(1-T D_{t-1}/A T_{t-1})$ ,where $T D_{t-1}$ and $A T_{t-1}$ are the 1-year lagged Compustat variables for total debt and total assets, respectively.  

Panel F (Equity returns of value-weighted $B/M$ -quintile portfolios) of Table 5 presents the average value-weighted equity returns B/M-quintile portfolios. The model does not have financial leverage. For this reason, the asset returns from the model are converted to equity returns with financial leverage information from the Compustat sample. Specifically, equity returns are defined as asset returns divided by one plus the financial ratio value of the corresponding B/M quintile presented in panel A of Table 2.  

The target moments in panel G (Conditional CAPM estimates of value-weighted B/Mquintile portfolios) of Table 5 are the average annual alphas and betas from the conditional CAPM. The estimates from the conditional CAPM are conducted every year using monthly frequency data following the procedure in Lewellen and Nagel (2006). Following Dimson (1979) and Lewellen and Nagel (2006), the empirical conditional betas are corrected for biases in related to nonsynchronous return data. Specifically, the conditional beta of portfolio $i$ in year $y$ is defined as $\beta_{i y}\equiv\beta_{i y}^{0}+\beta_{i y}^{1}$ ,where $\beta_{i y}^{0}$ and $\beta_{i y}^{1}$ are the slopes of the time-series regression  

$$
R_{i,t}^{e}=\alpha_{i,y}+\beta_{i,y}^{0}R_{M,t}^{e}+\beta_{i,y}^{1}R_{M,t-1}^{e}+\epsilon_{i,t},
$$  

where $t$ represents each of the 12 months in year $y$ ， $i$ denotes the B/M-quintile portfolio, $R_{i t}^{e}$ is the return of the portfolio in excess of the risk-free rate at month $t$ , and $R_{M,t}^{e}$ and $R_{M,t-1}^{e}$ represent the excess returns of the market portfolio at months $t$ and $t-1$ , respectively. The intercept $\alpha_{i,y}$ of the regression above is the annual alpha of the conditional CAPM. The B/M quintile portfolios from the model are the same as the ones used in panel F of Table 5 discussed above. The average conditional alphas and betas presented in the table are the time-series averages of $\beta_{i y}$ and $\alpha_{i,y}$ . The equity returns of the market portfolio in the model are defined as the value-weighted levered returns of the B/M-quintile portfolios from the model defined above.  

Finally, the estimates presented in panel H (Unconditional CAPM estimates of valueweighted B/M-quintile portfolios) of Table 5 are constructed regressions similar to that in Equation (D25), but where a single regression estimated over the entire sample period is used for each of the quintile portfolios.

# Table5 Model calibration: Summary of targeted and simulated moments  

The table shows the moments targeted by the model's calibration and the simulated moments generated by the calibrated model. The simulated moments are based on 1,000 simulated panels of data generated by the calibrated model. Each panel is populated by the histories of 1,000 firms over 792 months. The first 50 simulated years are used to generate the cross-sectional distributions for productivity and wages, and the remaining 16 years are used in the simulated moments shown below. The baseline decomposition is based on the value spread decomposition from Cohen, Polk, and Vuolteenaho (2003) into components related to post-formation cross-sectional variation in realized stock returns (i.e., the value premium), earnings growth (i.e., the growth spread), and future bm (i.e., the Value spread persistence). The ertended decomposition cross-sectionally decomposes the value spread into a component explained and a component orthogonal to the cross-section of labor shares. The target and model moments from the decompositions shown below are based on twenty portfolios of (real or simulated) stocks sorted on lagged bm. The parameter values used in the calibrated model are shown in Table 3.

# Shareholder litigation rights and labor investment efficiency Trung K. Doa, Anh-Tuan Le b," Department ofEconomics,Danang Architecture University,Danang,Vietnam b Department of Finance, National Central University, Taiwan # ARTICLEINFO # ABSTRACT JEL classification: E24 G31 G38 Keywords: Shareholder litigation rights Universal demand laws Labor investment efficiency This paper investigates the effect of shareholder litigation rights on labor investment efficiency. Using a difference-in-differences approach based on the staggered adoption of universal demand (UD) laws, we find that firms incorporated in states that have adopted UD laws experience lower labor investment efficiency. Furthermore, the negative association between UD law adoption and efficient labor investment is more concentrated in firms exposed to higher shareholder litigation risk ex ante and high-skilled labor firms. Our evidence is consistent with the notion of the passage of UD laws strengthens agency problems, and thus reduces labor investment efficiency. ## 1. Introduction The legal protection of shareholders rights is well-recognized as an essential determinant of corporate governance (Shleifer and Vishny, 1997). The law allows shareholders to bring lawsuits against corporate management when they feel that managers inappropriately exploit their control positions. Ferris et al. (2007), for example, find that following shareholder lawsuits, firms reduce board size and increase outside representation, suggesting an effective corporate governance mechanism of shareholder litigation rights. In this paper, we examine how changes in shareholders’ ability to make legal claims against managers affect investment decisions, especially labor investment efficiency. To isolate the effects of shareholders litigation rights, we employ a quasi-natural experiment on staggered state-level adoption of universal demand (UD) laws. Since the late 1980s, 23 U.S. states have adopted UD laws. The adoption of UD laws has significantly weakened shareholders? litigation rights by raising procedural hurdles to initiate derivative lawsuits (Davis Jr, 2008). As a result, the laws weaken the governance power of shareholder litigation, and thus it becomes more difficult for shareholders to correct manager's misconduct. Indeed, Appel (2019) finds that firms tend to adopt governance provisions that entrench managers, limit shareholder's voice, and have lower blockholder ownership following the passage of UD laws. To the extent that the adoption of UD laws decreases the external discipline power of shareholder litigation, thereby exacerbating the managerial agency problem, it could be easier for self-interested managers to entrench and reduce labor investment efficiency. Furthermore, Ni and Yin (2018) document that weaker shareholder litigation rights following the adoption of UD laws lead to a higher cost of private debt. Hence, firms may face financial constraints after the law adoption, which lead to sub-optimal investment in labor (Caggese and Cunat, 2008; Caggese et al., 2019). Overall, this line of argument suggests that firms, following the passage of UD laws, are likely to decrease efficient labor investment. Using an extensive U.S. data of 60,841 firm-year observations from 1984 to 2010, we find that firms incorporated in states that have passed UD laws experience higher abnormal net hiring, indicating lower labor investment efficiency. The adoption of UD laws generates sub-optimal decisions under the forms of over-investment (i.e., over-hiring). Additional analyses reveal that the negative effect of UD laws on labor investment efficiency is more concentrated among firms that are ex ante more likely to face derivative lawsuits (measured by managerial entrenchment and institutional ownership concentration) and high-skilled labor firms This study contributes to several strands of existing literature. First, our work adds to the vein of growing research exploring determinants of labor investment efficiency, which is critical for firms in productions and businesses. However, the economic consequence of corporate law changes made at the state level on labor investment remains scarce in the literature. Prior research mainly focuses on the role of various firm-level aspects that curbs efficient corporate investment such as financial report quality Jung et al., 2014), stock price informativeness (Ben-Nasr and Alshwer, 2016), and financial constraints (Caggese et al., 2019). Our analysis focuses on managers' litigation risk from changes in policy at the state level, which potentially affect investment decisions at the firm level. Second, this study is closest to emerging studies on the effect of shareholder litigation rights. Advocates for shareholder litigation believe that the threat of shareholder litigation may benefit firms in reducing agency problems via limiting managers' ability to introduce governance provisions, thereby serving as an effective corporate governance mechanism (Ferris et al., 2007; Appel, 2019). In contrast, other scholars document the dark side of shareholder litigation, which is often frivolous, harms defendant firms' reputation, and increases external financing costs (Deng et al., 2014; Arena, 2018; Nguyen et al., 2018). We shed light on this debate by demonstrating weakened litigation rights for shareholders due to UD law adoption lead them to face greater agency conflicts, which ultimately translates into lower labor investment efficiency. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the data, variables, and empirical design. Section 3 presents and discusses our empirical results. Section 4 concludes. ## 2. Data and methodology ### 2.1. Data selection Following Bourveau et al. (2018), we collect the dataset on the historical state of incorporation for U.S. public firms posted on Bill McDonald's website, which provides relevant data based on firms' SEC electronic filings on EDGAR since 1994.1 For observations prior to 1994, we use the earliest reported state. For firms missing in the dataset, we use the state of incorporation information provided by Compustat. Based on this information of the adoption of UD laws shown in Table 1, we construct a dummy variable, ${\mathrm{UD}}_{\mathrm{it}},$ whichtakes one for firm i incorporated in a state that adopted the UD law by the fiscal year end t, and zero otherwise. We employ accounting and stock return data from Compustat and CRSP, respectively. Industry-level data on labor union membership are collected from Hirsch and Macpherson (2003). After excluding financial and utility firms, our data includes 60,841 firm-year observations covering the period 1984 - 2010.2 To reduce the influence of outliers, we winsorize all continuous variables at $1\%$ level for both sides. For cross-sectional tests, we use data on the corporate governance index (Gompers et al., 2003) provided by the ISS director database and institutional ownership from the Thomson Reuters 13F database. ### 2.2. Measure of labor investment inefficiency Following Pinnuck and Lillis (2007) and Khedmati et al. We control for several factors that are documented in the literature (Jung et al., 2014; Ben-Nasr and Alshwer, 2016; Khedmati et al., 2019), including firm size, market-to-book ratio, financial leverage, tangible assets, liquidity ratio, financial report quality, dividend policy, reported loss, revenue volatility, net hiring volatility, abnormal investment in non-labor activities, labor intensity, union coverage. Definitions of all variables are provided in Appendix. We further control for firm and year fixed effects to deal with time-invariant unobservable variables, which further address bias due to the omitted variables. Table 2 presents summary statistics of all the variables. The mean and standard deviation of Ab_NetHire are $15.4\%$ and $21.9\%$ respectively. UD indicator has a mean of 0.102, representing that $10.2\%$ of the firm-year observations were affected by the UD laws. ## 3. Results and discussion ### 3.1. Main results We report the estimation results of Eq. (2) in Table 3. In Column (1), we only include UD indicator in the model whereas we add all control variables in Column (2). As is shown, we find that the estimated coefficients on UD indicator are positive and statistically significant at $5\%$ level in both columns. In terms of significant magnitude, the adoption of UD laws increases firm abnormal net hiring by $0.009-0.011$ ,which is equivalent to $5.84\%-7.14\%$ of its sample mean. This finding is consistent with the notion that UD law adoption reduces the efficiency of labor investment. In addition, we find that shareholder litigation laws increase abnormal net hiring under forms of over-investment (i.e., over-hiring).3 In Column (3) of Table 3, we include four dummy variables, namely UD (-1), UD (0), UD $(+1)$ andUD $(2+)$ equal to one if a state where firms incorporate that will pass the law next year, passes the law this year, passed the law one year ago, and passed the law two or more years ago, respectively. Interestingly, we find the coefficients on UD $(+1)$ and UD $(2+)$ are all positive and significant at the $10\%$ level. However, there is no significant relation between UD $(-1)$ and UD (O) and abnormal net hiring. These results indicate that the increase in abnormal net hiring is correlated to the adoption of UD laws instead of time trends. ### 3.2. Robustness checks #### 3.2.1. Controlling for possible confounding effects We next conduct several tests to ensure the robustness of our findings. First, Chu (2017) indicates that shareholders face difficulties engaging in class actions lawsuits due to a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruling in 1999. To discriminate against class action lawsuits, we exclude observations in the Ninth Circuit states: Alabama, Arizona, California, Hawai, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington. As the regression result is shown in Column (1) of Panel A of Table 4, the coefficient on UD indicator remains positive and statistically significant, implying that the relationship between UD laws and corporate employment decisions cannot attribute to confound law changes regarding class action lawsuits. Second, it is worth noting that many firms tend to choose to run their business in Delaware due to corporation-friendly laws and tax benefits (Daines, 2001). This raises a question that the Delaware effect biases our findings on the impact of UD laws adoption and corporate employment decisions. To address this problem, we exclude firms incorporated in Delaware and re-examine our findings on this sample. As shown in Column (2) of Panel A of Table 4, the coefficient on UD indicator is still positive and statistically significant at the conventional level. Thereby, the Delaware effect does not confound our findings. Finally, our third check aims to rule out a possibility that our results are driven by some confounding law changes, which are positively associated with efficient labor investment. For example, the adoption of many anti-takeover laws (i.e., Business Combinations laws (BC laws), Poison Pill legislation (PP laws)) occurs during the sample period, leading to bias in the estimation results. Further, Nguyen et al. (2018) also argue that the passage of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) hampers shareholders' initiation of lawsuits. To address this issue, we include several confounding law changes as additional controls. We include three additional dummy variables (BC laws, PP laws, PSLRA). BC laws (PP laws) as a dummy variable is set to one for a state-year in which the BC law (PP law) is active, and zero otherwise. Similarly, PSLRA takes a value of one in the effective years of PSLRA, and zero otherwise. The results are reported in Model (3) of Panel A of Table 4. As is shown, the coefficients of UD indicator remain positive and significant, indicating that our findings are robust to controlling for the adoption of the BC laws, PP laws, and PSLRA. #### 3.2.2. Propensity score matching One may argue that differences in firm characteristics between treatment and control firms could partially drive our main results. Therefore, we additionally conduct a DiD analysis using propensityscore matching following prior studies Bourveau et al., 2018). The treatment group consists of firms incorporated in the states that adopted UD laws. In contrast, the control group consists of firms with similar characteristics but incorporated in the different states that have not adopted UD laws during our sample period. We match firms using one-to-one nearest neighbor propensity score matching, without replacement. We also include all control variables as in the baseline regression. The results are reported in Panel B of Table 4. We find that the main findings still hold, thereby mitigating a concern that self-selection bias, given the states that have adopted the UD laws might be different in terms of applying the laws. #### 3.2.3. Alternative measures of labor investment efficiency To provide more robust evidence, we consider two alternative definitions of labor investment efficiency. First, following Jung et al. (2014), we use the industry-level mean to capture a firm's deviation from its industry median as abnormal net hiring. Industries are classified by using 48-industry codes by Fama and French (1997). Second, we replace the net hiring in Eq. (1) with labor cost, and the difference between the actual and expected labor cost is then defined as the inefficient labor investment measure in Eq. (2), as suggested in Ben-Nasr and Alshwer (2016). The results of these tests are reported in Panel C of Table 4. We find that the coefficients on UD Indicator remain positive and significant, suggesting that our findings do not depend on our definition of labor investment efficiency. #### 3.2.4.Labor and non-labor investments The relation between the adoption of UD laws and labor investment efficiency may be driven by the relation between the adoption of UD laws and the efficiency of other investments (e.g., capital, research and development, advertising, and acquisition investments) due to the complementarity between these investments and labor (Ben-Nasr and Alshwer, 2016;Sualihu et al., 2021). # Organization Capital and the Cross-Section of Expected Returns  

ANDREA L.EISFELDT and DIMITRIS PAPANIKOLAOU\*  

## ABSTRACT  

Organization capital is a production factor that is embodied in the firm's key talent and has an efficiency that is firm specific. Hence, both shareholders and key talent have a claim to its cash flows. We develop a model in which the outside option of the key talent determines the share of firm cash fows that accrue to shareholders. This outside option varies systematically and renders firms with high organization capital riskier from shareholders’ perspective. We find that firms with more organization capital have average returns that are $4.6\%$ higher than firms with less organization capital.  

IN RECENT DECADES, INTANGIBLE capital has become an increasingly important factor of production. In many instances, such intangible capital is embodied in the firm's key employees. We refer to this type of intangible capital as organization capital and develop a structural model to analyze its effect on asset prices. We argue that shareholders consider firms with high levels of organization capital to be riskier than firms with more physical capital, and provide empirical evidence supporting this claim.  

Organization capital is a durable input in production that is distinct from physical capital. In our model, the distinguishing features of organization capital are that its efficiency is partly firm specific and that it is embodied in the firm's key talent. Together, these two characteristics imply that both shareholders and key talent have a claim on the cash flows accruing from organization capital. Since shareholders can appropriate only a fraction of the cash fows from organization capital, investing in firms with high organization capital exposes them to additional risks.  

The cash fows that accrue to shareholders are determined in part by the division of surplus between shareholders and key talent. In our model, this sharing rule depends on the shock to the level of productivity of organization capital deployed in new firms, which we refer to as the level of frontier organization capital technology. This shock determines the outside option of key talent and hence the share of cash flows from organization capital that shareholders can appropriate.  

As a result, shareholders′ cash flows from physical and organization capital have different risk exposures to the frontier technology shock. If the frontier technology shock is correlated with shareholders’ marginal utility, heterogeneity in firms' asset composition between physical and organization capital leads to differences in risk premia, as shareholders demand compensation for the additional risk they are exposed to.  

To study the empirical relation between organization capital and risk premia, we construct a measure of organization capital using widely available accounting data. Following the accounting literature on measuring organization capital (see, e.g., Lev and Radhakrishnan (2005), we measure the stock of organization capital by cumulating firms' selling, general, and administrative (SG&A) expenses using the perpetual inventory method. We rank firms based on their ratio of organization capital to book assets relative to their industry peers $(O/K)$ , since the accounting treatment of SG&A expenses varies across industries.  

Our measure of organization capital is correlated with a number of firm characteristics in a manner that is consistent with our model. We find that high$O/K$ firms are more productive, smaller, have higher Tobin's $Q$ anddisplay higher levels of executive compensation. In addition, high- $O/K$ firmshave higher managerial quality scores according to the measure of Bloom and Van Reenen (2007), spend more on information technology (IT), and are more likely to list “loss of key personnel" as a risk factor in their 10-K filings. Furthermore, our model implies that the sensitivity of firm profits to firm output increases with the ratio of organization to physical capital, whereas the sensitivity of firm profits to aggregate output is the same across firms. We find support for these implications in the data.  

The evidence suggests that shareholders demand higher risk premia to invest in firms with high levels of organization capital relative to firms with more physical capital. We document this difference in risk premia by constructing a portfolio that is long firms with more organization capital relative to their peers (high- $O/K)$ and short firms with more physical capital relative to their peers (low- $O/K)$ . The portfolio of firms with high- $O/K$ minus low- $O/K$ (the OMK portfolio) has average returns of $4.7\%$ per year and a Sharpe ratio close to the market portfolio. Moreover, the OMK portfolio is uncorrelated with other risk factors such as the market portfolio, size, value, or momentum. Thus, the dispersion in expected returns arising from heterogeneity in the ratio of organization capital to assets is not explained by the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), Fama and French (1993), or Carhart (1997) models.  

Our model implies that this spread in average returns arises because the OMK portfolio is negatively correlated with the systematic frontier technology shock. Empirically, we find that a two-factor model that includes the market and the OMK portfolio prices the cross-section of firms sorted on $O/K$ orontheir beta with the OMK portfolio. In addition, and consistent with our model, the realized return of the OMK portfolio is negatively correlated with the aggregate level of compensation to key talent, the level of reallocation, and the level of investment in organization capital.  

We calibrate our structural model and show that it can quantitatively replicate our empirical findings. Our model matches the dispersion in firm characteristics and risk premia associated with organization capital. In our calibration, we assume that the frontier technology shock carries a negative risk premium. An improvement in the frontier technology leads to more restructuring and reallocation of organization capital from old firms to new firms. Since restructuring entails substantial costs in the short run, this assumption is consistent with general equilibrium. We also provide generalized method of moments (GMM) estimates of the market price of risk associated with the frontier technology shock, and find that it is negative for all three of our proxies for the frontier shock.  

In summary, our work identifies a new source of risk for shareholders: systematic fuctuations in the division of surplus between key talent and shareholders. From the perspective of shareholders, investing in key talent and organization capital is risky, since, unlike physical capital, shareholders do not own all ofthe cash fow rights. Key talent may leave the firm when their outside option exceeds their inside value. Consequently, organization capital has risk characteristics distinct from those of physical capital, and the risk inherent in this type of specific and intangible form of capital requires significant risk premia.  

Our paper belongs to a growing body of work that explores the role of organization capital in the production process and analyzes its properties (Prescott and Visscher (1980), Hall (2000b), Atkeson and Kehoe (2005), Carlin, Chowdhry, and Garmaise (2011), Lustig, Syverson, and Van Nieuwerburgh (2011). The closest paper to ours is Lustig, Syverson, and Van Nieuwerburgh (2011), who argue that the growing importance of organization capital in the production process is one of the leading causes of the observed increase in compensation inequality and pay-for-performance sensitivity, and the accompanying decrease in labor market reallocation. Our work builds upon Atkeson and Kehoe (2005) and Lustig, Syverson, and Van Nieuwerburgh (2011), to introduce a common stochastic component in the productivity of organization capital in new firms, or frontier technology using the language of Atkeson and Kehoe (2005).  

Moreover, our paper is related to the production-based asset pricing literature (Cochrane (1991, 1996) and in particular to models with endogenous production (Berk, Green, and Naik (1999), Gomes, Kogan, and Zhang (2003), Zhang (2005), Bazdrech, Belo, and Lin (2009)). Most of these models feature a single aggregate shock and generate heterogeneity in asset risk premia through endogenous movements in conditional betas with the market portfolio. In contrast, our model generates heterogeneity in asset risk premia through exposure to a second systematic source of risk, the frontier level of technology, which affects the division of surplus between shareholders and key talent. This systematic shock is an example of technical change embodied in human capital. The macroeconomic literature argues that human-capital-embodied technological change is important for understanding the dynamic behavior of income inequality in the data (Chari and Hopenhayn (1991), Greenwood (1999), Krusell Ohanian, Rios-Rull, and Volante. (2000)).  

Our model captures the idea that key talent and shareholders have a joint claim on the cash fows produced by the firm. Mounting evidence suggests that executives significantly affect corporate outcomes (Bertrand and Schoar (2003), Adams, Almeida, and Ferreira (2009), Graham, Harvey, and Puri (2009), Bennedsen, Pérez-Gonzalez, and Wolfenzon (2011)). In addition, pay of corporate executives accounts for a significant fraction of corporate earnings. Bebchuk (2005) documents that the ratio of executive pay to corporate earnings has risen dramatically in recent years. New evidence suggests that broader classifications of key talent are also important for firm performance. Bernstein (2012) documents the departure of skilled inventors in firms post-IPO, which is associated with a subsequent decline in innovation activity. On the valuation side, Tate and Yang (2011) provide evidence using matched worker/plant data that high-skill workers in diversified firms have better ex-post outcomes following plant closures. Using our model, they argue that the diversification discount may be due to the higher outside option of skilled labor in diversified firms.  

There are inherent difficulties involved in the measurement of organization capital (Blair and Wallman (2001), Black and Lynch (2005)). Black and Lynch (2005, p. 206) argue that one of the main difficulties is that organization capital “cannot be wholly controlled by the firm." Our measure of organization capital is motivated by Lev and Radhakrishnan (2005), who argue that firm SG&A expenditures create corporate value through the formation of organization capital. A number of papers in the organization literature measure the quality of the firm's organizational structure and management practices using surveys (Caroli and Van Reenen (2001), Bresnahan, Brynjolfsson, and Hitt (2002), Bloom and Van Reenen (2007)). Our measure has the advantage that it is readily available for a long time period and a large number of firms. The second alternative method of measuring organization capital is as a residual from a structural model. While this methodology avoids some of the difficulties inherent in measuring intangibles, the resulting estimates are sensitive to the model specification. McGrattan and Prescott (2001) and Hall (2000a, 2001) argue that intangible capital played an important role in the valuation of the U.S. corporate sector in the 1990s. Using a structural model with technology adoption, Atkeson and Kehoe (2005) estimate that the payment fows to the owners of organization capital constitute $8\%$ of output for manufacturing firms. Hansen, Heaton, and Li (2005) measure intangible capital by requiring that the risk adjusted investment returns to total capital be equal across firms.  

The rest of the paper is organized as follows Section I develops our modeling framework, Section II details our procedure for measuring organization capital, Section IHI explores the model's predictions, and Section IV concludes. Details on data construction are delegated to the Appendix.  

## 1. Model  

We develop a model illustrating how, from shareholders' perspective, investment in organization capital entails different risks from investment in physical capital. In our view, there are two defining characteristics of organization capital. First, organization capital is embodied in highly specialized labor inputs, and thus is distinct from physical capital. We refer to these specialized labor inputs as key talent throughout the paper, examples of which are management and technical personnel that are essential to the firm. Second, the effciency of organization capital is specific to the firm, which distinguishes it from general human capital. Hence, an alternative to organization capital could be firm-specific human capital, consistent with the views in Prescott and Visscher (1980). Under this more narrow definition, one could view investment in organization capital as expenditures on hiring and training key talent. Hired and trained key talent would increase overall firm cash fow, but would require higher compensation when their outside option improved.  

The unique nature of organization capital implies that both shareholders and key talent have a claim to its cash fows. In particular, organization capital is embodied in key talent, and is therefore potentially movable across firms. As a result, key talent can extract a payment from shareholders equal to their outside option. The value of this claim depends on the efficiency of organization capital in new firms. Shareholders have a claim to the residual cash fows, and the value of this claim depends on the difference between the inside and outside value of organization capital. Furthermore, systematic movements in the efficiency of organization capital in new firms lead to systematic movements in the division of organization capital rents between shareholders and key talent. Therefore, shareholders investing in firms with organization capital areexposedto additionalrisks.  

We first present a simple model in Section I.A that illustrates these ideas and yields closed-form solutions. We extend the basic model along a number of dimensions in Section I.B. The extended model yields additional predictions and helps us assess the quantitative importance of organization capital in explaining the cross section of expected returns.  

### A. Basic Model  

There exists a continuum of frms that produce a common output good using physical capital $K$ and organization capital $O$ . Given an endowment of physical and organization capital, firm $i$ produces a flow of output given by  

$$
y_{i,t}=\theta_{t}K_{i}+\theta_{t}e^{\varepsilon_{i}}O_{i}.
$$  

Both capital stocks are subject to an aggregate, disembodied technology shock $\theta$ . In addition, the productivity of the firm's stock of organization capital $O_{i}$ depends on the efficiency of that firm's organization $\varepsilon_{i}$ . The level of efficiency $\varepsilon_{i}$ can be viewed as the quality of the match between the firm and key talent. The firm-specificity of $\varepsilon$ captures the idea that part of the knowledge embodied in organization capital is specific to the firm. For now we assume that the endowment of physical capital $K_{i}$ and organization capital $O_{i}$ , as well as the efficiency of the firm's organization $\varepsilon_{i}$ , are constant over time.1  

The total factor productivity (TFP) shock $\theta$ evolves according to a geometric random walk,  

$$
d\theta_{t}=\sigma_{\theta}\theta_{t}d Z_{t}^{\theta},
$$  

where $d Z_{t}^{\theta}$ is a Wiener process and $\sigma_{\theta}$ corresponds to the volatility of the common TFP shock $\theta$ . The productivity shock $\theta$ affects physical and organization capital symmetrically, thus all firms have the same sensitivity of revenue to $\theta$  

In the spirit of Atkeson and Kehoe (2005), new technologies that improve the frontier efficiency of organization capital emerge over time. Key talent can either upgrade the organizational efficiency in the existing firm (restructure) or leave the existing firm along with part of the accumulated knowledge and existing organization structure $O$ to a newly created firm (reallocation).2 Given the existence of this outside option, key talent can always extract all of the surplus from restructuring. Creating a new firm requires a positive amount of physical capital $K_{i}$ . Key talent can buy this physical capital at its competitive market price, and finance this purchase by issuing shares in the new firm. Existing shareholders are thus indifferent between selling their claim to physical capital $K_{i}$ to key talent or restructuring the existing firm. As a result, the model is silent as to the form of the technology adoption process. For parsimony, in our discussion of the model we assume the former.  

Our model implies that new technologies are adopted through a process of creation and destruction, whereby inefficient organization technologies are replaced with the frontier level of organizational efficiency. This process of creation and destruction can be interpreted in several ways. For instance, if the shareholders in the new firm are different from the shareholders in the existing frm, then this process resembles a management buy-out, a start-up, or other form of venture financing, depending on how the purchase of physical capital is financed. Alternatively, if the shareholders in the old firm also own shares in the new firm, then we can interpret this process as a restructuring event. In this case, when the firm decides to upgrade its organization capital, the firm undergoes a period of extensive reorganization that leads to a higher level of organization efficiency.

From shareholders’ perspective, firms with more organization capital are exposed to additional risks. Firms in this economy are exposed to two distinct sources of risk, namely, the productivity shock $\theta$ and the frontier shock $x$ . The shock $\theta$ affects the productivity of all capital. Hence, all firms have the same exposure to $\theta$ ,as we see from the second term in equation (14). By contrast, firms' exposure to the technology shock $x$ is increasing in their ratio of organization to physical capital $O/K$ , which is captured by the last term in equation (14).

All firms have the same exposure to the TFP shock $\theta$ ,and therefore crosssectional differences in risk premia are driven by heterogeneity in the ratio of organization to physical capital $O/K$ The price of risk of the frontier shock $\gamma_{x}$ determines whether organization capital commands a higher or lower risk premium than physical capital. In our calibration in Section II.A, we argue that a negative risk premium for the frontier shock $x$ is consistent with economic intuition and the difference in average returns between firms with high- and low-organization capital. In Section III.E, we find that the GMM estimate for the market price of frontier shock risk is negative using three proxies for the frontier shock $x$  

The model presented thus far captures the main intuition of the paper. Organization capital is exposed to an additional source of risk relative to physical capital, because shareholders do not necessarily appropriate all the benefits accruing from it. In particular, shareholders receive lower payments from organization capital when the outside option of key talent improves. Shareholders demand compensation for this risk because the outside option of key talent varies with the state of the economy. In particular, this outside option depends on the productivity of organization capital deployed in new firms, which in our model is captured by the frontier technology shock $x$ . An increase in the frontier shock $x$ reduces the share of cash flows that shareholders can extract from organization capital. As a result, heterogeneity in firms' asset composition $O_{i}/K_{i}$ leads to differences in risk exposure to the frontier technology $x$ and differences in risk premia.  

### B.Extended Model  

In this section, we extend the model in Section I.A to allow for endogenous accumulation of physical and organization capital. In addition, we allow the option to upgrade to the new technology to remain active regardless of whether the firm has done so in the past. To ensure that this option is infrequently exercised, we allow for costs to reallocating organization capital. These extensions do not qualitatively affect our inferences derived from the model in Section I.A, but instead generate additional testable predictions that help to validate the model.  

As before, there exists a continuum of firms that produce a fow of output givenby  

$$
y_{i,t}=\theta_{t}e^{u_{i t}}K_{i t}+\theta_{t}e^{\varepsilon_{i t}}O_{i t}.
$$  

The output of the firm is affected by an aggregate disembodied productivity shock $\theta$ , whose evolution is given by  

$$
d\theta_{t}=\mu_{\theta}\theta_{t}d t+\sigma_{\theta}\theta_{t}d Z_{t}^{\theta}.
$$  

The productivity of a firm's physical and organization capital has firm-specific components $u_{i}$ and $\varepsilon_{i}$ , respectively. These firm-specific shocks evolve according to  

$$
d u_{i,t}=-\kappa_{u}u_{i,t}d t+\sigma_{u}d Z_{t}^{u_{i}},
$$  

$$
d\varepsilon_{i,t}=-\kappa_{\varepsilon}\varepsilon_{i,t}d t+\sigma_{\varepsilon}d Z_{t}^{\varepsilon_{i}}.
$$  

The firm can accumulate physical and organization capital over time through investment  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{d K_{i t}=(i_{K i t}-\delta_{K})K_{i t}d t,}\ {{}}\ {d O_{i t}=(i_{O i t}-\delta_{O})O_{i t}d t.}\end{array}
$$  

Here, $i_{K}$ and $i_{O}$ represent the firm's investment in physical and organization capital, respectively. Physical capital depreciates at a rate $\delta_{K}$ as it physically deteriorates or becomes obsolete. Similarly, organization capital depreciates at arate $\delta o$ either because it becomes obsolete or because key talent retires.  

The firm can increase its stock of physical capital by an absolute amount $i_{K}K$ bypurchasing $c_{k}/{\lambda_{k}i_{K}^{\lambda_{k}}K}$ units of the investment good at a relative price $\xi_{t}=c_{q}\theta_{t}$ .4 Therefore, the total output cost of increasing the physical capital stock by an absolute amount $i_{K}K$ equals  

$$
C_{K}(i_{K},K;\theta)=\theta\frac{c_{k}c_{q}}{\lambda_{k}}i_{K}^{\lambda_{k}}K.
$$  

In our investment cost formulation (22), the values of the parameters $c_{k}>0$ and $\lambda_{k}>1$ capture the degree of steepness and convexity of the adjustment cost function. Moreover, the marginal cost of investing in physical capital increases in the TFP shock $\theta$  

In addition, the firm can expend resources and increase its stock of organizationcapital $O_{i}$ . The firm can increase its stock of organization capital by an absoluteamount $i_{O}O$ at a total output cost of  

$$
C_{{\cal O}}(i_{{\cal O}},{\cal O};\theta)=\theta\frac{c_{{\scriptscriptstyle o}}}{\lambda_{o}}i_{{\cal O}}^{\lambda_{o}}{\cal O}.
$$  

Just like physical capital, the creation of new organization capital is subject to convex costs, parameterized by $\lambda_{o}>1$ and $c_{o}>0$ . In addition, the marginal cost of investment in organization capital increases with the common productivity shock $\theta$ , which can be interpreted as a congestion cost. For instance, if investment in organization capital requires an input whose supply is independent of $\theta$ (i.e., worker time), then the marginal cost would be increasing in $\theta$ just as in the case of investment goods.  

Similar to the model described in Section I.A, new technologies that improve the frontier efficiency of organization capital emerge over time. In contrast to the model in Section I.A, the option to adopt the new technology can be exercised multiple times. In particular, after the new technology is adopted, the efficiency of organization capital evolves stochastically according to equation (19). Thus, it may be optimal for key talent to adopt a new technology again in the future. To ensure that the equilibrium distribution of firm-specific productivity levels $\varepsilon_{i}$ is stationary, we assume a mean-reverting formulation for $x$  

$$
d x_{t}=-\kappa_{x}x_{t}d t+\sigma_{x}d Z_{t}^{x}.
$$  

In contrast to the basic model in Section I.A, adopting the new level of organization efficiency $x$ is costly. Specifically, upgrading an amount $O$ of organization capital to the frontier level of technology involves a cost equal to:  

$$
C_{R}(O;\theta)=c_{R}\theta O.
$$  

This assumption is consistent with the findings of Foster, Haltiwanger, and Krizan (2001), who show that reallocation is accompanied by a costly period of learning. Without loss of generality, we assume that this cost is paid by the key talent. This cost could arise if part of the accumulated knowledge embedded in $O$ becomes obsolete with the new technology, if there are interruptions of the production process due to the necessary retraining of workers and adjustment of the organization structure to the new technology, or if there are setup or financing costs involved in starting a new firm.
